div.p: 1. V. Friday.— Philadelphia.

Employed the morning before breakfast in writing to my wife— Breakfasted at the Lady’s ordinary, to which Judge Baldwin of the Supreme Court of the United States had recommended me, and who was the only person present whom I knew— After breakfast I was going to Mr Biddle’s when I met Mr John Sergeant, who told me he had concluded to go on by the Steamboat at one O’Clock this afternoon, to reach Baltimore this Evening, and Washington to-morrow morning. He had heard that Charles J. Ingersoll, had authenticated a protest against the return of his competitor, Mr Naylor, and had perhaps done it to prevent Naylor’s voting upon the election of the Speaker— He, Sergeant, must therefore hasten to Washington, to look to the possibility of unfair practices, and counteract them— I found Mr Biddle, in bed—much flushed, and with a feverish hand—but relieved from the violence of the attack which was an inflammation of the kidneys—free from pain, and cheerful and good humoured as is his habitual character— He made me promise to dine, and pass the night at his house, and sent for a few friends, to come and dine with me.— I had a long conversation with him upon the affairs of the Banks, banking and the currency; but found him fully convinced that the resumption of specie payments by the Banks will for an indefinite period of time be impracticable— He thinks the recent proposal of the deposit Banks in New-York for a convention of delegates from Banks throughout the Union, to determine upon a time for the simultaneous return to cash payments, was a mere stratagem to procure the restoration to them of the public deposits— That they well knew, when they made the proposal, that cash payments could not be resumed till the foreign debt shall be paid; and made the proposal, to plume themselves upon it and gain credit for the performance, under the delusion of a false promise— He said James Hamilton of Charleston, South-Carolina, who first proposed in a Letter to him, this Convention of Banks, had been here and was now in New-York— That he had warmly urged this measure upon him, but that he had told Hamilton, that so sure as the attempt to resume should be made, so sure it would prove a fallacy and an abortion— It could not be maintained a week.— He told me that the Bank of the United States, had now eleven hundred thousand dollars of the money to be paid by them to the Treasury of the United States, in October for the first instalment of the Stock owned by the United States in the late Bank, in Treasury drafts, and that he expected when the time of payment should come to have the whole sum, in the same paper currency, so that the Bank will pay the whole instalment without disbursing a hard dollar.— After this conversation I went to the Bank of the United-States, and presented to Mr Jaudon the Cashier 850 dollars in the Bills both of the old and of the new Bank, for which I asked payment by an order on Washington— He gave me an order on Richard Smith, Cashier of the late Branch, and now agent of the Bank there; payable in current Bills— I took it without remark—for in my judgment upon the proceedings of the Bank of the United States, I wish to avoid mingling any possible
possible private interest of my own; but the adroitness with which this order changed the nature of my demand upon the bank could not escape my observation— I brought to Mr Jaudon Bills payable on demand, in cash— He gave me an order payable in current bills, depreciated from 8 to 12 per cent.— I then went to the Anti-Slavery Office 223 Arch-Street—thence to Samuel Webb’s house, and afterwards to Benjamin Lundy’s Office— I saw and had long conversations with them both, and with two or three others whom I found with them—of whom was Mr Buffum who told me he was a hatter— Lundy returned with me to my lodgings. He and the abolitionists generally are constantly urging me to indiscreet movements which would ruin me and weaken and not strengthen their cause— My own family on the other hand that is my wife and Son and Mary exercise all the influence they possess to restrain and divert me from all connection with the abolitionists, and with their cause— Between these adverse impulses my mind is agitated almost to distraction. The public mind in my own district and State is convulsed between the Slavery and abolition questions, and I walk on this edge of a precipice in every step that I take— After Mr Lundy left me, I took a Letter for my wife to the Post-Office, and returned to Mr Biddle’s to dine— He could not leave his bed, but his brother, Commodore James Biddle, and his Son Charles did the honours of the table. Joseph R. Ingersoll, and Dr Sutherland were of the company— Sutherland said he was going for Washington to-morrow— After the company were gone, I had another Conversation with Mr Biddle, and then went to the weekly meeting of the American Philosophical Society where I met Dr Mease, Mr John Vaughan, Mr Du Ponceau, Dr Harlan, Coll. Totten, and some others— I subscribed my name in a book containing a new and elegantly written list of the members of the Society— Returned to Mr Biddle’s for the Night, about 10 O’Clock.
2. V. Saturday
From Philadelphia to Washington

I did not see Mr Biddle this morning, but his Son Charles told me that he continued better— I was unwilling to disturb his repose so early, and at 7 O’Clock left his House, and went on board the Steamboat Telegraph Captain Whilden— Sutherland was on board; and several members of both houses of Congress, among whom Williams of Maine, Swift, a Senator from Vermont, and Cranston of Rhode-Island. At Wilmington, we took the cars of the new Railway to Baltimore— Mr John Connell went a few miles with us from Wilmington, and Mr Newkirk, one of the Directors of the company, who was exceedingly polite to me. I had seen him yesterday at Mr Biddle’s.— We arrived at Baltimore, at half past two O’Clock— The Railway is a stupendous work; accomplished chiefly by means of loans from the Bank of the United States— The road is indeed uncommonly level the whole way; but the bridges over numerous creeks, and the abutments of the passage of the Susquehanna at Havre de Grace, were heavy and costly undertakings.— The passage is accomplished in a Steamboat in five minutes; and tables are all laid in the boat for the breakfast of the Passengers from Baltimore to Philadelphia— Those from Philadelphia
to Baltimore, breakfast in the Steamboat before they reach Wilmington— The road is almost the whole way through a forest, chiefly of Oak; so that there are no pleasant prospects to cheer the passenger— On arriving at Baltimore I went with Mr. Jenifer, a member of the House of Representatives from Maryland, to Barnum’s tavern, where we dined at the Lady’s Ordinary— Mr Hubbard a Senator from New-Hampshire was also at the table, and Mr French a Sub clerk in the Office of the Clerk of the House of Representatives— After dinner I paid a visit to Mr and Mrs Gorham Brooks, and then went to the Depot of the Cars of the Railway for Washington— At half past five we departed from Baltimore, and landing at the foot of Capitol Hill at half-past eight, I took a hack, and reached my house, at Washington just at the stroke of nine— Mrs Wilson, who now lives at the French Ministers came and opened the door for me, and Mrs Goods had all in readiness to receive me— Wilson is with the French Minister at Philadelphia— I retired immediately to bed.
3. V. Sunday.

At the Presbyterian Church—morning service I heard Mr Fowler from 1. John 4.8. “God is love.”— A very affectionate text, perhaps not so appropriate to Calvinistic doctrines, as to those of some other denominations of Christians— Mr Swift the Senator from Vermont, and Mr Elisha Whittlesey of Ohio, attended in my pew. after Church I walked up to the Capitol; and took my Seat in the House of Representatives—the same, that I occupied in the 23d. and 24th. Congresses— It is if not the best, one of the best Seats in the House— My name was upon it, and although not taken in person, no member had exercised the privilege, of having it effaced, and substituting his own in its stead. Mr William S. Smith had called on me this morning, and invited me to dine with him; and Robert Buchanan had called on me just before Church— I dined with Mr Smith, and Robert Buchanan, and Thomas J. Frye were there; after dinner Mrs Smith went with me to St. John’s Church, and heard Mr Hawley read the Evening service for the 15th. Sunday after Trinity and preach from Luke 12.32 [“]Fear not, little flock; for it is your father’s good pleasure, to give you the kingdom.” Mr Hawley a very worthy man preached as usual— Mrs Smith observed that he did not improve— After the service Mrs Frye and Mrs Smith came over, and sat with me half an hour.— Mr Maxwell a member of the House of Representatives from New Jersey was introduced to me this day, and gave me a Letter from Mr Saml. L. Southard the Senator.
4. IV:30. Monday

Morning visits from Dr Huntt and William C. Greenleaf.— The Doctor says his health is better than it was last Spring; but he looks very much emaciated— He enquired particularly of the complaint of my wife in her left eye, and advised her on her passage through New-York, to consult Dr Kearney Rogers whom he thinks the most eminent oculist in the United States.— William C. Greenleaf is living at
at judge Cranch’s, without profitable occupation— His application for employment at the Patent Office having been unsuccessful. He asked me, if I should hear of any situation in which he could be useful to speak a good word for him, which I would most willingly do— The first Session of the 25th. Congress commenced this day— I attended at the Capitol, half an hour before the usual time of meeting; which was spent in mutual gratulations and greetings with the old members returned anew, and with introductions of new members.— At noon precisely Walter S. Franklin, the Clerk of the last House of Representatives, called the Meeting to order, and read over a roll of the members, by States, which he had gathered from the Newspapers When he reached the State of Mississippi, Charles F. Mercer of Virginia, objected to their admission to vote for Speaker; and offered a Resolution, that SamuelGholson, and John F. H. Claiborne had not produced satisfactory evidence of their election as members of the House, upon which an acrimonious debate of two hours arose, which terminated in laying Mercer’s Resolution on the table— Gholson and Claiborne were elected in the face of the Constitution of the United States, for this single Session; that is until superseded by an election to be held next November; which was admitted and avowed by Gholson and Claiborne—but they bullied the meeting into an admission of them to vote, by threatening to call for the certificates of election of every person present—not one in five of whom, perhaps not one in ten had his certificate with him— An exceedingly irregular practice having within a few years crept in, of requiring no certificates of election from the members, but swearing them in, upon mere newspaper report— I took no part in this debate; though I had my certificate with me, and was satisfied that the Mississippi election was null and void— Still the men from Mississippi had been elected by a large majority of the People of the State, who in the event of their exclusion from the House would be unrepresented the whole of the present Session. I was therefore content to wave the Constitutional illegality and let them in—224 members answered to the call of their names.— The votes for Speaker were for James K. Polk of Tennessee 116. for John Bell of Tennessee 103. and 5 scattering— So Polk was elected by a majority of 4 votes— At the last Congress he had a majority of 48. I voted for Bell— My neighbour John M Patton voted for Joseph W. Jones of Virginia— Polk on being conducted by Governor Lincoln and Owens of Georgia to the Chair, made a clumsy address to the House, in which he said it would be impossible for him to keep order unless supported by the House, which was true enough as an appeal to the party majority; but he promised impartiality which if he does practice at all will be only between the two sides of his own party— Lewis Williams of North-Carolina, called the father of the house swore in the Speaker, and the Speaker swore all the other members present, by States— John Sergeant nominated Samuel Shock of Pennsylvania for Clerk— But Walter S. Franklin, was re-elected by a vote of 146. to 48 for Shock and 15 scattering— Roderick Dorsey was by nomination and vote reappointed Sergeant at Arms. Overton Carr, principal Door-keeper and William S. Hunter assistant Doorkeeper
Doorkeeper.— A motion was made to adopt the Rules and Orders of the last Congress, to which Mr Mercer moved an exception of the rule for appointing a Committee of Elections for the revisal of which he proposed the appointment of a select Committee. I moved as an amendment, that the Report of the Committee for revising the rules made at the first Session of the last Congress should be referred to the same Committee. After some debate on this motion the House adjourned— A Message had been received from the Senate, announcing that they had formed a Quorum—and appointed a Committee on their part to wait on the President and inform him that a Quorum of both Houses was assembled, and ready to receive from him any communication—the joint Committee on the part of the House was appointed, but the Message to the Senate to inform them of the choice by the House of a Speaker was neglected, till after the Senate had adjourned— It was past six O’Clock when I got home to dinner— Weary evening.
5. IV:15 Tuesday.

Morning call from Robert Buchanan and visit from Mr Henry Clay; also from Mr Taliaferro of Virginia Mr Slade of Vermont, and all the members of the New Jersey delegation in the house, but one— H.R.U.S. James Garland reported that the joint Committee had waited upon the President of the United States, who had informed them that he would this day at Noon communicate to the two houses a message in writing. The message was accordingly delivered immediately after by the President’s Son, Abraham Van Buren— It occupied an hour and a half in the reading, and was confined exclusively to the subject of the currency and the condition of the Revenue. Hamer of Ohio moved that ten thousand copies should be printed—Owens of Georgia moved for 20,000—Whittlesey of Ohio, objected to 20,000 and made a speech— He was not answered, but Hamer had accepted Owens’s increased number, and upon taking the question by yeas and nays it was carried 115 to 109. The Report of the Secretary of the Treasury upon the finances was then received— Connor of North-Carolina, moved that 20000 copies of that should also be printed—another member moved 10,000 and that was carried by a vote of 106. to 101.— These two votes disclose the fluctuation, of the administration majority in the house.— Patton of Virginia, moved to proceed to the election of a Printer to the House— Lewis Williams of North-Carolina nominated Gales and Seaton— Hamer, nominated Blair and Rives, and John C. Clark of New-York nominated Thomas Allen— At the first ballot there were 230 votes—103 for Blair and Rives, 100 for Gales and Seaton 22 for Thomas Allen—1 for Duff Green, and 4 for blanks— There were five ballottings, without material variation from the first— Blair and Rives had once 104. Gales and Seaton once 103. Thomas Allen at the fourth ballot had 23. Between 5 and 6 O’Clock the House adjourned— Patton told me that the 22, were ten from New-York, 9. from Virginia and 3 from Illinois—one of the last however doubtful. I found I could not work this Evening.
6. II:30. Wednesday.

A person by the name of John Gardiner came to explain to me an invention which he claimed as his own of a life-preserver, which was no other than the old Cork Jacket— He proposes to petition Congress for a reward for this notable discovery. Other visitors came, and he said he would call again— Dr Kraitsir and Mr Zerrlaut two of the Polish exiles came and informed me that they were about to open a classical school at Ellicott’s Mills near Baltimore—and appeared to desire some recommendation from me— They promised to come again— Morning visits from Messrs Fletcher, Cushing and Hastings, members of the Massachusetts delegation— Antoine M. Giusta was here— I enquired of him if he had with him my Notes upon which interest is due— He had them not, but said he would bring them to-morrow. Mrs Frye, and Mrs Smith also called to see me.— Mr Frye had been here on Monday; and invited me to dine with them every day.— I told him it was too far to walk after a long Session at the Capitol; but that I would come the first leisure day. I rose this morning between two and three O’Clock; which I propose to do every day, when I wake at that time; for I can neither read nor write by evening lamplight, and I can in the morning.— H:R.U.S. The day was consumed in fruitless struggles to elect a public Printer— There had been a Van Buren Caucus last Evening; and when the subject was called up this morning Isaac H. Bronson, a New-York Administration member, moved a Resolution to suspend the balloting for printer till the third Monday in September, and that temporarily and until the election of a printer, the Clerk be authorised to employ some person or persons to do the printing on the same terms upon which it was done at the last Session. This proposition gave rise to a long debate, and many proposed amendments— George Grennell of Massachusetts moved to lay it on the table, which was rejected by yeas and nays 109 to 114. Pickens of South-Carolina, moved an amendment that the printing should be given by contract to the lowest bidder. Sherrod Williams that it should not be an editor of a Newspaper; but withdrew his amendment.— Coles and Robertson of Virginia were for separating the public printing from all Newspaper printers.— Hoffman of New-York made his maiden Speech, severely scoring the globe— John Reed, proposed that besides the preference of the lowest bidder the quality of the paper should also be prescribed— Picken’s’s amendment was carried 112 to 109. but Cambreleng then opposed the Resolution— Wise proposed that the printing should be divided between the Editors of the Madisonian and of the National Intelligencer— M’Kennan then moved to lay all the propositions on the table which was carried without yeas and nays though called for by Montgomery—117 ayes. So the house resumed balloting, and on the 6th. 7th. and 8th. ballots, the votes for Gales and Seaton fell from 93 to 81 and 68. and those of Thomas Allen increased to 27. 42. 53— The sixth Ballot gave Blair and Rives 107 votes but on the 7th. and 8th they fell to 101— Slade moved to adjourn but that was lost.— Taylor of New-York moved a Resolution, that the printer of the House at the last Congress be authorized to print for the House till a public printer shall be elected— Patton moved to lay the Resolution on the Table— Taylor called for the yeas and nays—123 to 100. Boon of Indiana, moved a Resolution that the members of the House should vote by viva voce— Patton moved to extend the Rule, to all officers eligible by the House, much
much debate upon this; till Robertson of Virginia moved to postpone the further consideration of the Resolution till to-morrow, when he would offer a Resolution for severing the public printing from the political press— At near six O’Clock, on the motion of Glascock of Georgia, the House adjourned— I came home wearied out, to an idle evening and an early bed.
7. II:45 Thursday.

Though rising at this hour, I have not half the time necessary for accomplishing my indispensable obligations, among which is that of chasing Time in the record of this diary which is running again into irretrievable arrears— Giusta was here again this morning, with my notes, and I paid him 150 dollars for one year’s interest, upon my note of 3000 dollars dated 5. July 1836. 50 dollars a year’s interest on my note of 1000 dollars dated 6. May 1835. and 189:97 in full, for my note of 8 May last to John Walker, payable in forty days, and endorsed by him; including 2:50 for interest since the 17th. of June— I paid him therefore 389 dollars 97 cents—for which I gave him four 100 dollar Bills of the defunct Bills of the Bank of the United States. For Mr Jaudon having given me an order on Richard Smith Cashier of the Bank of the United States here payable only in current Bills I received the payment in Bills of the same Bank of the United States— H.R.U.S. After the reading of the Journal, Robertson moved his amendment, to Boon’s Resolutions for choosing the Printer viva voce, but after some debate they were all laid on the table— Graves offered a Resolution that Thomas Allen should be employed for the printing, till a printer should be chosen— He withdrew the motion— A ninth ballot was taken 228 votes. Blair and Rives 104 Gales and Seaton 48 Thomas Allen 70. Blank 3. scattering 3.— It was now apparent that Allen would be chosen— Howard of Maryland moved to suspend the balloting till the third Monday in September, and that in the meantime the printers to the House at the last Congress should be employed— Another Speech, answered by Patton, who moved to lay Howard’s Resolution on the Table— Harrison of Missouri called for the yeas and nays, and they were 116 to 107 for laying on the table— Harrison moved that in the future ballotings, the name with the fewest votes should be dropped. M’Kay of North-Carolina, argued that Blair and Rives having received a plurality of votes might be considered as elected; which Patton said was not sound doctrine for the democracy of numbers.— Harrisons motion was laid on the table, and the 10th. 11th. and 12th ballots were taken; in which the votes for Gales and Seaton were 21. 8 and 9. those for Thomas Allen were 99. 111. and 113.—and the whole number of votes being 225. Thomas Allen, was at the last ballot elected— I had voted the first ten ballots, for Gales and Seaton— The last two I voted for Allen, seeing that the only alternative was between him and the lying rascals of the Globe.— After the election was completed Whittlesey of Ohio moved to take up the Resolution for the revisal of the Rules—
Mercer had moved that the Rules of the last House should be adopted excepting that for the appointment of a Committee of Elections, and that for the revisal of that a select Committee should be appointed— I had moved that the Report of the Committee on the Rules made at the first Session of the last Congress should be referred to the same Committee— An entire revisal of the rules was now proposed, and that the Rules of the last House should be adopted for ten days— After much manoeuvering by Hamer of Ohio, he succeeded in carrying a substitute for Mercer’s Resolution, that a Committee should be appointed to revise the rules, and that the Rules of the last House should be adopted for ten days, with the exception of the 107th rule—which is that no change of the rules shall be adopted without one days notice, or by less than two thirds of the votes. Whittlesey of Ohio then moved for the appointment of the standing Committees, which was agreed to— Richard Biddle of Pennsylvania, member from Pittsburgh, brother of Nicholas, offered a Resolution calling upon the Secretary of the Treasury to report whether a Letter purporting to be addressed by him to the Clerk of the House, offering payment in specie to members of Congress is authentic: if so, to what other claimants on the Treasury, a similar offer has been made, and what principle of discrimination, if any has been adopted in the medium of payment to the public creditors— It lays over one day.— Adjourned near 6 O’Clock— I received a Letter from Mr Abbott Lawrence which I have not time to answer— I met this morning Mr Kent—a Senator from Maryland, riding to the Capitol, and at his invitation took a seat with him—
8. III:30. Friday.

Dr Kraitsir and Mr Zerrlaut, called again, and gave me further particulars of their intended Academical school at Ellicott’s Mills, near Baltimore— Their main object was to obtain my permission to refer enquirers to me, for their characters, to which I readily consented; believing them to be respectable and intelligent, as certainly in the predicament of Polish exiles they are very unfortunate men— While they were here a young man by the name and style of the Revd. Charles Lester, and a young woman of the Society of Friends named Mary L. Cox came in— Mr Lester introduced himself as a Clergyman, and a Grandson of the celebrated Dr Jonathan Edwards. He introduced also the young woman.— Dr Kraitsir and Mr Zerrlaut withdrew. The young woman brought a Letter from Benjamin Lundy who had told me that she was desirous to see me— She said she had a spiritual impulse, that it was her duty to address a discourse to me, if I had no objection to hearing her— I said I should on the contrary be greatly obliged to her— She then began a regular Quaker Sermon, of about a quarter of an hour, exactly such as I had heard before, from Harriet Livermore, Elizabeth Lambert and Elizabeth Fry.— Their Sermons consist of passages from the mystical and minatory passages in the writings, of the Apostles, especially of Paul, strung together by a few words of incessant application, delivered in a half way tone between speaking and chanting—or what the French call unction— She appeared to be deeply affected, with great modesty in her manner, and an intense conviction of the importance of what she said—a canto of commonplaces from the Epistles of the New Testament— The discourse
discourse was altogether hortatory to me; and prayerful that I may be sustained and fortified by divine assistance and support— Conscious of needing it as I am, I could not but receive with profound sensibility these exhortations and prayers— I thanked her cordially for them, and assured her that I should be encouraged by them to persevere in the course that I had hitherto pursued; and I requested her to continue to me the benefit of her prayers— Mr Lester told me that he was a Presbyterian, and asked me whether I was a member of any church— I told him I was, and had for nearly eleven years been a member of the Congregational Church at Quincy; the same of which my father, and his ancestors have been members from the first formation of the Church in 1639. Mr Lester took a minute of the names of my Ancestors up to the first Henry Adams— He invited me to take a seat in the Carriage in which he was going to the Capitol, which I did— Mary L. Cox alighted at her lodgings in Pennsylvania Avenue— He then told me that she was wholly a stranger to him— They had met at the same lodgings, and he had accompanied her to my house as a matter of courtesy. She appeared desirous of obtaining the use of the Hall of the House of Representatives, to preach in next Sunday and asked me to speak for her to Mr Potts, to make the request, which I promised— At the House, Robertson offered an amendment to the Resolution presented yesterday by Richard Biddle, and both were ordered to be printed. John Bell of Tennessee announced to the House the death of James Standefer of that State, on his way to this place as a member elect of the present Congress. Bell eulogized him in appropriate terms, as a worthy respectable man, without lofty pretensions— He moved the usual resolution, to wear crape thirty days, and to adjourn, which the house did over to Monday— I saw Mr Nicholas Biddle’s Son Charles at the Capitol.— Robert Buchanan was here this Evening. He is going on a visit into Virginia; and asked me for some lines for a Miss Goldsborough. I received a Letter from my wife, written on the receipt of mine from New-York.
9. IV:30. Saturday.

Morning visits from Mr M’Kay, a member of the House from North-Carolina, Mr Childs, member from Rochester, New-York, and Mr Allen, member from Vermont, with Mrs Allen, and their Son;—Mrs Allen came, in the belief that Mrs Adams and Mary were here— I took the two sets of Mr Ammidon’s papers to the Department of State; and left them there; the Secretary, Mr Forsyth being absent from indisposition, and the chief Clerk Mr Dayton, likewise absent— The papers are all of a date as early as 1822. They are, a Letter to the Emperor of China, signed by James Monroe then President of the United States—a Letter to the Viceroy of Canton signed by me, as Secretary of State, and a Letter signed also by me, to James Wilcocks then Consul of the United States at Canton— The Letter from Mr Ammidon to me, states that the Letter to the Vice-roy of Canton was delivered; but that probably the
the one to the Emperor never was— It was recommendatory of an application in behalf of the owners of the Ship President Adams, wrecked on the Coast of China, and plundered by the People on the shore, and praying for indemnity— The request of Mr Ammidon now is for a renovation of these same papers by the present President and Secretary of State—and that one copy of them may be delivered to Mr Ammidon, and another to the Captain of the first ship of War, which may be ordered to the China Seas— These papers were first procured by Jonathan Russell, who had been supercargo of the Ship President Adams, and was perhaps interested in the claim.— They are now fifteen years old, and there is little prospect of a second edition of them being more efficient than they were before— I called at the President’s House, and spent half an hour in conversation with him respecting the weather, the climate, and Queen Victoria, the girl of 18 sovereign of all the British dominions— “Youth at the prow, and pleasure at the helm”— I had been told that in these troublous times, Mr Van-Buren was so deeply affected by them, that he looked extremely wretched; but I found no such thing— He had every appearance of composure and tranquility— He spoke indeed of the cares and afflictions of the Station which he now occupies, and said it was surprising how universal the delusion was, that any one could be happy in it, and he spoke of the calm philosophical Spirit of Dr. Franklin and of Mr Madison—who he said had expressed to him a very high esteem for me— There are many features in the character of Mr Van Buren strongly resembling that of Mr Madison— His calmness—his gentleness of manners. his discretion—his easy and conciliatory temper— But Madison had none of his obsequiousness—his sycophancy—his profound dissimulation and duplicity— In the last of these he much more resembles Jefferson, though with very little of his genius— The most disgusting part of his character his fawning servility belonged neither to Jefferson nor to Madison— I went to the Pension office and left with Mr Edwards the Commissioner, the papers of Elizabeth Perry, given to me by Joshua Curtis of Abington; those of the children of Captain Joseph Allen, which I received from Mr Minott Thayer of Braintree; and those of Lucy Holbrook, Olive Lovell and Ruth Bates handed to me by Mr Lemuel Humphrey of Weymouth. These are all widow’s Pension claims.— After this I went and dined at Mr Frye’s; without previous notice to Mrs Frye— Captain Wade of the army, who married one of the daughters of Andrew Buchanan, Mrs Frye’s first husband, was there— Her Son Robert went this morning to Virginia— Returning home, I called on Mr and Mrs W. S. Smith, who invited me to dine with them to-morrow— I received this morning a Letter from my granddaughter Mary-Louisa Adams, now in the ninth year of her age— O! may a gracious Providence watch over these orphans!
10. IV:30. Sunday.

Morning service at the Presbyterian Church. heard Mr Fowler from Genesis 3.4. “And the serpent said unto the woman, ye shall not surely die.” There is a grammatical inaccuracy in this phrase— The translation should have been ye shall surely not die— The negation is of death, and not of its certainty— I dined at Mr W. S. Smith’s— Thomas J. Frye was there— After dinner I attended at St. John’s Church. Mr Hawley read the Evening service for the 16th. Sunday after Trinity, and preached a short discourse from Psalm 47.5. “God is gone up with a shout, the Lord, with the sound of a trumpet. 6. Sing praises to God, sing praises; sing praises unto our king, sing praises. 7. For God is the king of all the earth: sing ye praises with understanding.” The text was more animated than the Sermon— Evening visit from Mr Stephen C Phillips. He told me that there had been a meeting of a small number of the members of the party now calling themselves whigs, in which it was agreed that they should oppose the passage of the bill to postpone the payment of the fourth instalment of the deposit with the States, payable on the first of October next, and amounting to upwards of nine Millions of dollars— The bill has been reported in both Houses of Congress, and will probably pass in both—undoubtedly in the Senate I told Mr Phillips I was sorry they had agreed to oppose it, for it was indispensably necessary—and unless the payment should be postponed the money must be raised by a loan, saddling ten Millions more of debt upon the People— He said Mr Clay had urged it upon the meeting— Mr Clay was in so great a hurry, that he took ground of opposition, the very first moment after the reading of the President’s message. Neither of the Senators from Massachusetts, Webster or Davis is here— I said to Mr Phillips that the whigs must be exceedingly cautious, in determining what they should oppose; or they would have the popular feeling turned against them, and play into the hands of the Administration— I answered the Letter from my Granddaughter Mary-Louisa, and have begun upon a short biographical memoir of my father, for Mr James Herring.
11. IV. Monday.

General Macomb called on me this morning, and invited me to dine with him, and a few of his friends; it being the anniversary of the battle of Plattsburg.— Accepted the invitation. I had received a Letter from William Bates of Wareham, enclosing a Patent to a person named Bump, with several assignments, and 18 dollars in bank-bills, for a new and modified Patent— I took them all to the Patent Office, and left them with the Commissioner Henry L Ellsworth. He told me however that instead of 18 dollars there should have been 27. and instead of Bank-bills, coin, for that no bank bills were now received at the Patent-Office— He said also that to obtain a modified Patent, the old one must be surrendered, and there must be a specification of the principle claimed for the new one— He took all the Papers and said he would write to me concerning them to-morrow. At the House, Crary of Michigan, Yell, of Arkansas, Lewis of Alabama, and Cheatham of Tennessee were sworn and took their Seats— The standing Committees were announced—Cambreleng Chairman of the Ways and Means, Smith of the Committee of Commerce, Howard
Howard of the foreign Affairs, and Thomas of the Judiciary, all rank Van Burenites— I am still Chairman of the Committee of manufactures, which has this Session nothing to do— Buchanan of Pennsylvania, a new member is chairman of the Committee of Elections—three others of the members are new— A majority Slave holders and a majority though not the same persons administration men.— To make sure work of the Committee of Foreign Affairs, Hamer of Ohio is placed next to Howard, and in the event of his removal becomes by the usage Chairman of the Committee— There are six Slave holders on the Committee upon the District of Columbia, with Bouldin of Virginia at their head— The party drill, on both points of slavery, and administration is complete.— Richard Biddle’s call upon the Secretary of the Treasury, to explain why he pays members of Congress in gold, and other public creditors in rags, with Robertson’s Amendment, which Biddle accepted, was taken up, and supported by Biddle, in a handsome speech— Hamer of Ohio, and M’Kay of North-Carolina, laboured hard to counteract its force—but in vain— Neither of them ventured to oppose the resolution— Hamer’s argument was that it would be but fair to hear the Secretary’s explanation before condemning him, and that he would give an explanation perfectly satisfactory— He was also shocked at the idea that any member of Congress should be influenced by so paltry a consideration as the premium upon gold over bank paper. M’Kay drew a fallacious parallel between the option offered to members of Congress to receive their pay in gold, and that to other creditors to receive their pay in current bills, or not be paid at all.— The Resolution was adopted.— Bell of Tennessee offered a Resolution calling upon the Secretary of the Treasury to report what appropriations may be dispensed with, which at Cambreleng’s recommendation was immediately adopted without opposition— The House went into Committee of the whole on the State of the Union, upon the President’s Message— The Speaker called me to the chair— Cambreleng offered two Resolutions, one referring so much of the Message as related to the finances to the Committee of ways and means—the other referring so much as related to a bankrupt law, to the Committee on the judiciary—both were adopted without opposition, reported to the House, and immediately concurred in— Cambreleng moved to distribute in like manner, the Report of the Secretary of the Treasury, between the same two Committees— Ewing of Ohio offered an amendment which was rejected, and Cambreleng’s motion adopted— Smith of Maine, offered a Resolution that the action of the standing Committees on all matters not embraced by the Message of P.U.S. be suspended until the commencement of the annual Session in December; and that the consideration of all petitions on such suspended matters be suspended to the same time— Whittlesey of Ohio, urged an exception in favour of private claims— Williams of North-Carolina moved to postpone the consideration of the question till Wednesday— Bell supported this motion, and broke out against the sub-treasury project of the message— Cambreleng replied—supported the sub-treasury project—and called upon the opposition to propose their Bank of the United States— This led to a long skirmishing debate
debate in which motions to except the Committee of Claims, and even the Committee of Elections were rejected, without allowing the vote to be taken by yeas and nays— This only proves the determination, almost unanimous of the house to have a short Session— The Senate had already suspended the action, and even the appointment of most of their standing Committees— The House adjourned soon after 3. I dined with General Macomb— Messrs. Gilpin, Solicitor of the Treasury, Whitcomb, Commissioner of the General Land-Office, Christie of New-Orleans, General Gratiot, Coll. Abert, Major Macomb, and the General’s son Alexander were of the party— Mrs Macomb the only Lady at the table. I toasted the Memory of Plattsburg— The General was in high Spirits— I came home about 8 O’Clock— Idle Evening—
12. IV:30. Tuesday.

Dr Feuchtwanger, brought me a Letter of introduction from Coll. Abert.— He has a project for contracting to coin cents from a composition of zinc, copper and nickel, called German silver— He has coined counters with his name, and one cent stamped upon them, of which he shewed me several— They are clean, and about the size of a ten cent piece— He makes table furniture and all Articles usually plated of the same composition, costing about one fourth as much, and looking nearly as well as silver— He had a memorial which he wished me to present, but I advised him to make some alterations in it— And I suggested to him the expediency, of having a coinage of 2 and 3. cent pieces of his composition, instead of throwing the copper coinage of cents out of circulation.— I received an answer from the Commissioner of Patents, returning some of the Papers received from William Bates, and the 18 dollars in Bank Bills, all which I enclosed to Mr Bates. A man by the name of Samuel Heinecke, brought me a subscription paper, for building a methodist episcopal Church for the people of colour.— H.R.U.S. Cambreleng, Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means, reported a Bill to postpone the fourth instalment of deposite with the State—twice read, and referred to the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union. Cambreleng said he should probably report two more Bills to-morrow— Garland moved to proceed to the choice of a chaplain, and nominated the Revd. Mr Tuston— This Gentleman had called upon me some days since, and mentioned that he was the person who had baptized a child at Leesburg in August 1825 when I was there with Mr. Monroe, and General La Fayette— An incident in itself interesting, but rendered deeply pathetic by the circumstance, told me afterwards by Dr Wallace, that the child died that very Night, though at the time of the baptism apparently well— Mr Tuston shewed me also Letters very strongly commendatory of him, from George Tucker, professor of moral philosophy at the University of Virginia; and from Henry St. George Tucker his cousin— I had promised Mr Tuston to vote for him, and did so. He was elected at the second ballot— Haynes of Georgia then moved to adjourn; and withdrew the motion, to allow me to offer, separately three Resolutions, calling upon the President of the United States 1. for the correspondence with Mexico, relating to the boundary; and
and especially to any proposal to the Mexican Government, for a cession of territory from that republic to the United States— 2. Whether any proposition has been made by the Republic of Texas, to be annexed to the United States, and if so what answer has been returned to it, and all the correspondence relating thereto. 3. For copies of the correspondence with the British Government relating to our North-eastern Boundary, since the message of the late President to the Senate of 15. June 1836— To the first and third of these Resolutions I added the usual restriction, so far as the public interest may permit; but omitted it in the second— The Resolutions lie over one day for consideration— The House adjourned about 2. O’Clock— Mr Harmar Denny, late member of the House from Pittsburgh, but not now a member came this morning to my Seat, and told me there was a Convention of Anti-Masons sitting here in a room, at Brown’s Hotel— That they were to meet at one O’Clock; and would be glad if I could find it convenient to attend.— I promised him I would, if the house should adjourn in time— I went accordingly, and found about fifty persons assembled— The principal deputation was from Pennsylvania— Ner Middleswarth was in the Chair, and among the Members were Darlington, M’Kennon, Biddle and Ogle of the House of Representatives— Denny and Todd of the House heretofore; and Thaddeus Stevens— I found them in debate, upon Resolutions honorary to W. H. Harrison as past and future Candidate for the Office of President of the United States, and to Joseph Ritner as Governor of Pennsylvania, and candidate for re-election— The resolutions were discussed about half an hour and finally withdrawn—and the meeting adjourned to meet again hereafter. 2d. Tuesday Novr. 1838 at Philadelphia. It was a convocation invited by the Anti-Masonic Committee of Pennsylvania, to consult about a nomination of a Candidate for the Presidency, at the next election— But with the exception of one member from Rhode-Island named Williams, there was no representation from any State other than Pennsylvania— I came home, and drudged for the remainder of the day and Evening.
13. II:45. Wednesday

Morning visits from Messrs Darlington, Todd, and Stevens, the last of whom is a native of Massachusetts, settled in Pennsylvania, and a remarkable man—likely hereafter to figure in the history of this Union— Todd was formerly distinguished as the leader in Congress of the band, who carried through the Tariff of 1824. He is I believe now a Judge in Pennsylvania— Dr Feuchtwanger brought me his memorial, and a number of his Counter cents— Mr Frye called and invited me to dine with him to-day. H.R.U.S. The Speaker had hesitated, some time whether he should call for Petitions at this Session at-all. He had first on Monday announced that he would call for them, and then said it was suggested to him that it was usual for the Speaker to give one day’s notice before calling for Petitions, and he accordingly gave that notice— Smith’s resolution to suspend the action of the Committees, was intended to arrest the presentation of Petitions, but he did not dare introduce it expressly into the Resolution, nor did the Speaker dare to infer from it their exclusion. He accordingly called
accordingly called this morning for petitions— Very few were presented I presented Dr Feuchtwanger’s Memorial, which as it related to the currency was referred to the Committee of Ways and Means— I presented also the memorial of Charles Blight for the children of Robert Fulton; which Mr John Connell had sent me; and was laid on the table.— Mr Cambreleng from the Committee of Ways and means reported a Bill, to authorize the issuing of twelve Millions of dollars of Treasury Notes—twice read and referred to the Committee of the whole House on the state of the Union— Mercer from the select Committee on the Rules and Orders of the House, made a report in part, which was ordered to be printed, and made the special order of the day for to-morrow— My Resolutions were then taken up— The first was suffered to pass without opposition. Howard, Chairman of the Committee of Foreign Affairs, stipulating that the subject was not to be debated at the present Session; to which I assented— Much and various opposition was made to the second— Wise declared that he should vote against it, because he had positive information from high authority that the correspondence on the subject was not in a condition to be made public— But Wise was not in the true secret— The correspondence to which he alluded is extra-official and will not be given— The South-Carolinians, and Howard, Chairman of the Committee of Foreign Affairs thought best to yield to the call; Wise got a hint that the secret correspondence was in no danger of being disclosed, and withdrew his objection to the call— Haynes of Georgia moved to insert the restrictive exception, so far as may be compatible with the public interest, and the House agreed to insert them— Haynes and Holsey indulged their slave-holding spite in silly personalities to which I made no reply— Cushing towards the close of the debate, enquired of Wise, where he got the information of an existing secret Correspondence, not in a condition to be now divulged; and Wise declined to answer— To my third Resolution Howard proposed an addition, of the correspondence between the Department of State and the Governor of the State of Maine, relating to the subject; which I accepted; and the Resolution passed without opposition.— I then presented a Resolution that the clerk procure and cause to be printed—for the use of the house, copies of the Acts of the several State Legislatures, authorizing and relating to the suspension of specie payments by the Banks respectively chartered by them— This was adopted without opposition— The House adjourned about 3. I dined at Mr Frye’s— Mrs Lear was there— But neither Captain Wade, nor Thomas J. Frye was there— Robert Buchanan is yet in Virginia— On my way home, I called for half an hour at Mr W. S. Smith’s.
14. III:30. Thursday

Dr Feuchtwanger came again this morning. I told him that his memorial had been referred to the Committee of Ways and Means, and advised him to see and converse with the Chairman and members of the Committee concerning it. I called at the Office of the Secretary of the Treasury, and left with him the papers delivered to me for that purpose by Mr Russell Freeman— They were recommendations for
for his restoration to the Office of Collector of the Port of New-Bedford, which he held in my time, but which President Jackson gave to Lemuel Williams— Mr Woodbury told me that Mr Williams had recently signified his wish to be re-appointed— As I came out from the Secretary’s chamber, I saw in the Anti-chamber Mr Charles J. Ingersoll, now a Sychophant of Van Buren, as he was late a sycophant of Jackson who turned him out of the Office of District Attorney at Philadelphia, and a demagogue of the school of Clodius and Vatinius— Those three brothers, sons of Jared Ingersoll are all men of fine talents, and of no moral principle— Edward has absconded from the eye of honest Society, for detected forgery— Joseph came into the last Congress as worthy of being the successor of Horace Binney, and went out of it the tool of Waddy Thompson, and the scorn of every freeman in the House— Charles has spent his life in hoarding riches screwed by extortion from the poor, and in boxing his political compass to every change of the wind— Federalist, Democrat, Tory, Jacobin, Tariffite, Bankite, Anti-tariff, Anti-Bank, black, white, gray, any colour any shape that the interest, and the popular breath of the moment required, but always under every shape and colour a rapacious extortioner, and an unblushing Sycophant. His talents, with his sycophancy keep him above water, in spite of an universal distrust of his integrity— Parties want him to do their dirty work, and they at once sustain and despise him. There are many such characters in this free republic. He is knight of the shire and represents them all— He was wanted by Van Buren, for his financier in the house, and there was a hard struggle to bring him in for the third District of Pennsylvania— Charles Naylor carried the election against him, and Ingersoll has trumped up a memorial from the district, to have the election set aside— But the Committee of Elections seem to think the chance of an election now would be worse than it was before, and they have not yet acted on the memorial.— H.R.U.S. I presented the Petition of Sherlock S. Gregory of Sandlake, Rensselaer County, New-York for an act of Congress declaring him an alien or stranger in the land, so long as Slavery exists, and the wrongs of the Indians are unrequited and unrepented of— The Petition lies on the table, but together with two or three remarks which I made on presenting it, it roused the wrath of Cushman of New-Hampshire, the man of previous questions, moved a resolution “that the operation of the 16th. rule of the House, in relation to the call of the States for presentation of Petitions be suspended during the present Session of Congress.” I saw his drift and immediately assailed his resolution as an attempt to abridge the right of petition. Tillinghast and Mercer came also to the rescue— Cushman was so confounded that he knew not what to say— Polk the Speaker, said he probably meant only to suspend the call of the States, and not the presentation of Petitions, and advised him to modify his Resolution accordingly. I objected to that—observing that it totally changed the character of the Resolution— I insisted upon the preservation of the form— The call of the States, and demanded the yeas and nays— Cushman was at his wits end— He said he was the last man in the world to abridge the right of petition—he was interrupted by calls from his own party to withdraw his Resolution, and awkwardly did withdraw it— Garland of Virginia, offered three Resolutions of Call upon the Secretary of the Treasury which were adopted; and the House
House took up the Report of the Committee of revisal of the rules. All the amendments proposed by the select Committee of the last Congress were now again reported, excepting one; which was that the previous question shall be applicable to pending amendments as well as to the primitive proposition to which they are appended— I had not originally proposed this amendment; but it was perhaps the most important to the freedom of debate of any reported by the former Committee but Hamer of Ohio, sly as a quaker, and sour as a presbyterian had got upon the Committee of the present Session, and prevailed on a majority of them to strike it out. I moved to restore it as an amendment; upon which a warm debate of two hours terminated in a vote of 106 to 102 by yeas and nays upon my amendment.— This was a strict party vote, and may be considered as shewing the administration party majority—in the House— Hamer had also contrived to introduce two other amendments into the present report of the Committee—one that after the call for the previous question, all questions of order shall be decided without debate— The Speaker, contrary to all precedent had decided at the last Session, that this was already the rule and had been sustained by the party drill in the House; but Hamer to make assurance doubly sure now got this Committee to propose it as an amendment of the Rules; and carried it notwithstanding the vehement opposition of Patton—but Hamer lost in the House another of his proposed amendments; which was to revoke the 107th rule, which requires a day’s notice, and a vote of two thirds to revoke or alter any of the standing rules— Hamer and Smith of Maine laboured very hard to carry this point, though I warned them that their majority was slipping out of their hands, and that their new screws would be turned against themselves— The House adjourned without taking the question— Evening weary.
15. III:30. Friday.

Morning visits from Mr Phillips, and Dr Barstow of Salem, who has been much out of health; and is now returning from the White sulphur springs of Virginia— H.R.U.S. I presented the petition of Ebenezer Smith, and 163 citizens of Ryegate, Vermont for retrenchment and reform— The words produced a general shout of laughter in the house—which was repeated when I said that my reason for presenting it was that among the reforms for which it called, one was that Congress should reduce the pay of the members of both houses from 8 dollars a day to four. It lies on the table, and is in reality an abolition petition. Governor Lincoln said that he had intended, after the Resolution of the House to confine its action to the subjects referred to in the President’s Message, to retain sundry Petitions of more than 3000 persons, his Constituents against the admission of Texas into the Union— But the extraordinary debate on my Resolutions for calls upon the President, had led him to think it his duty to present those petitions, which he did; moving that they should all lie on the table, giving notice that he should call them up, at any time when a proposition for annexing Texas to the Union may be before the House— Several other members also presented Petitions against the admission of Texas, but I reserved mine for another day— The Speaker laid before the House a statement of Appropriations for the last 2 years Cambreleng
Cambreleng from the Committee of Ways and Mans reported a Bill imposing additional duties as depositories, in certain cases on public Officers. This is the famous Sub-treasury scheme, which is to be the panacea for all the diseases of the Country— Twice read and referred to the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union— As was another Bill reported by Cambreleng, for adjusting the remaining claims on the late deposit Banks.— He said the Committee would have only two bills more to report. Garland said that when the Bills should be taken up— Bell was for acting immediately upon the Bills from the Senate; but Cambreleng said they were not in all respects identical with those reported by to the House.— They all came from the Treasury, and are very slightly varied in modification differently by the financial committees of the two houses respectively. The debate upon the rules was concluded.— Mercer having made from the Committee a further report— The rule that questions of order raised after a call for the previous question shall be decided without debate was carried by yeas and nays 103 to 96— But the proposed revocation of the 107th. rule, requiring a day’s notice, and a vote of two thirds to alter any of the standing rules, was lost after a sharp debate, by yeas and nays 88 to 221.— A proposed addition of two standing Committees of 5 members each, upon Patents, and upon the public buildings and grounds was adopted without opposition— So was much to my surprize a rule that during the sittings of the House, the members shall remain uncovered— From the first existence of the Government, the members of the House have been in the practice of wearing their hats, except when addressing the House— Numberless attempts have been to alter the rule, always till now without success.— It passed now without one word of objection, and gave me a signal illustration of the humours of deliberative assemblies, and how much depends upon the temper which they happen to be in, to carry a measure before them.— Mercer moved from the Committee that Jefferson’s Manual, should be authority in all applicable cases, not incompatible with the Rules of the House, or with the joint rules of the two Houses.— An order that no spirituous liquors should be offered for sale or exhibited within the Capitol, or on the adjacent public grounds, was also reported and adopted— Bell moved that no count by tellers should be in order but upon motions seconded by at least one fifth of a quorum of the members— Carried Underwood proposed that the Speaker in calling for Reports from the standing Committees he should name each of them in succession— Carried L. Lincoln proposed a rule that in the elections of the House by ballot, blanks should not be counted— Dawson moved that there should be a standing Committee on the mileage of the members, which much to the annoyance of Yell of Arkansas; and the Mississippi Members was adopted— Mercer then moved that the rules as amended, with Jefferson’s Manual as part of them should be printed for the use of the Members which was carried; including also the Constitution of the United States—and thus closed the revisal of the Rules; whether for better or for worse is yet to be seen— I sometimes think there are already too many rules, and that it would be better to have none at-all.— The House adjourned at 5. O’Clock, over to Monday.— I have been for some time occupied day and night when at home, in assorting and recording the Petitions and remonstrances against the annexation of Texas, and other anti-Slavery Petitions which flow upon me in torrents— I am compelled to suspend the biography for Mr Herring—
16. III:30 Saturday.

John Maul is the son of a German who was some years a messenger in the Department of State—in the latter part of his life, a useless hanger on and very troublesome— By the favour of Mr Monroe, he got this Son educated at West-Point, and a Commission of Captain in the army— He was dismissed at the reduction of the army in 1821. and has been a burden upon Society ever since. He came now to solicit my recommendation of him, to Overton Carr the door-keeper of the house, to employ him as a Messenger or Runner; and he looked like famine— He had written to me to make the same request— Mr Larned has been many years Charge d’Affaires of the United States, in Chili and Peru; and has very recently returned home— He gave me very unfavourable accounts of the condition of those Countries, though he thinks highly of the present President of Peru, GeneralHe holds his station by the wager of battle—he invaded Peru as commander in chief of an Army of the Republic of Bolivia—vanquished the Chief then at the head of the Peruvian Government, had him shot as a traitor, and took his place.— This was in Feby. 1836. and I alluded to it in my Speech on the 25th. of May of the same year. Peru and Bolivia are now to be united into one republic— They were separated only by the foolish ambition of Bolivar to have a Republic called by his name— I called at the Office of the Secretary of State, and saw Mr Forsyth— Met there Genl. Gratiot, andMiller, heretofore Governor of Missouri, and now one of the members of the House from that State— Mr Forsyth told me that William Tudor’s Brazilian Correspondence was now ready for communication to the House, and would be sent in next week. He spoke to me, about the reports of the two Commissioners under the 7th. Article of the Treaty of Ghent— They were made in Feby. 1828.— He had written to me to enquire what had been done at the time of their reception, as there are on the files of the Department no Documents to shew what was, or whether any thing was done— I presume that in fact nothing was done— There was an arbitration then pending upon the 5th. Article, involving the Maine boundary, not settled to this day—and while that was undecided, I presume, it was thought best to reserve further proceedings upon the disagreement between the Commissioners under the 7th. Article— The whole subject had entirely passed away from my Memory: but as Mr Clay was in Feby 1828 Secretary of State, I referred Mr Forsyth to him for the information desired, supposing that he would have some recollection of what was done concerning it— As to Mr. Ammidon’s Chinese papers Mr Forsyth said there was some difficulty in complying with his request, as there was no evidence to shew that the Hong Merchants had not presented the former papers to the Vice-roy of Canton— I asked him to write me a note, stating this difficulty, which I would communicate to Mr Ammidon, which he promised to do— He told me that the Correspondence with Mexico, with Texas, and with Great Britain concerning the North-eastern boundary would be sent in next week— He said that no proposition for the cession of Texas had ever been made to the Mexican Government— That when Butler had been Charge d’Affaires there, he came back here once all of a sudden, and made the old General believe that if he would give him sufficient
sufficient authority, he would not only make the proposition but would accomplish the object— He was furnished with the authority; sent back and never made the proposition— His reliance had been upon what he believed was the disposition of Santa Anna— From the Department of State I went to the Office of Mr Peter Force, the Mayor of the City— He is preparing a vast collection of antient documents relating to the History of this Country, and has a very great and curious collection of his own— Thence I called at the National Intelligencer Office and saw Mr Gales— Evening at home, and wrote to Jacob H. Loud, of Plymouth enclosing a Pension Certificate for Hannah Pierce.
17. IV:30. Sunday.

Heard at the Presbyterian Church, Mr Fowler from Psalm 89.14. “Justice and Judgment are the habitation of thy throne: mercy and truth shall go before they face:”— I believe the latter half of the verse was not included in the text.— The whole verse is in the loftiest style of oriental imagery— Justice and Judgment are a habitation; not of God himself, for the Heaven of Heavens cannot contain him, but of his throne— The seat of that is fixed, eternally fixed, in Justice and Judgment— Yet Justice and Judgment convey only the idea of the righteousness and power of God—to complete his attributes, Mercy becomes an indispensable element— The Psalmist accordingly says— Mercy and Truth shall go before his face—and why go before his face, but to enlighten his Justice and to mitigate his judgment.— Taken altogether the verse is one of thoe examples of the sublime and accurate conceptions of the deity, which abound in the old Testament, and which constitute its highest title to be revered as a direct revelation from God— It is in the calvinisitic Spirit of fear, to overlook the attribute of Mercy, while contemplating the Justice, and the power of God— Mr Fowler himself is evidently a benevolent, kind hearted man; but his Calvinistic education has taken from him the best part of his perceptions; and in leaving out the last half of the verse he was unconscious that he mutilated one of the most magnificent ideas of the Godhead that ever was committed to writing.— After dinner at St. John’s Church Mr Hawley read the service for the 17th. Sunday after Trinity, and preached one of his short Sermons from Romans 13.12. “The night, is far spent, the day is at hand: let us therefore cast off the works of darkness, and let us put on the armour of light.”— How figurative again is this language!— This epistle is a Letter of moral and religious instruction to the converts to Christianity at Rome— When he said to them that the night was far spent, and the day was at hand, he had reference to the condition of those to whom he wrote, and to the progress of the gospel dawn— It is difficult to see the application of this figure to the present times or to a Washington auditory. Mr Hawley however remarked the alternation of this figure of the transition between day and night, which occurs in the New Testament—here it is the passage from Night to day, when the works of darkness are to be cast off; and the armour of light to be assumed to fight the good fight of faith— Elsewhere it is said that the day is far spent— The faithful are therefore exhorted to work while it is day; because the Night cometh when no man can work— There is no inconsistency between these metaphors, although there
there may be some, in the language which clothes them— Mr Hawley did not trouble himself much to shew how the Night was far spent, and the day at hand to us— Mr Sergeant came somewhat belated to Church, and after the service, came home and spent an hour with me— Full of the news of the Election of Governor and members of the State Legislature in Maine, which is said to have turned most unexpectedly in favour of the whigs— I called and visited this Evening at Mr W. S. Smith’s and at General Macomb’s. Neither Mr Smith nor the General was at home— I saw the Ladies.
18. III:30. Monday

Call at the Bank of the Metropolis; with a check payable to Mary C. Adams, drawn last May, but which she declined then to take— I now received it—50 dollars in bills of the bank, and 50 dollars in a draught on the Commonwealth’s Bank at Boston, which I endorsed payable to her order, and enclosed to her.— I had received yesterday from Mr William L. Brent a Letter of enquiries in behalf of the Monk family, and the John Stokes concern— I called this morning at his Office to tell him all that I knew upon the subject, but he was not there. Met judge Nathaniel Pope. Call at the Bank of Washington, which has resumed specie payments of its own bills, and made a special deposit of 390 dollars in Bills of the Bank of the United States— H.R.U.S.— At my motion 2000 extra copies of the revised rules with Jefferson’s Manual and the Constitution of the United States be printed and by a suggestion of G. N. Briggs, suitably bound— I presented 90 Petitions and remonstrances against the annexation of Texas to the United States— Governor Lincoln presented the Resolves of the Legislature of Massachusetts concerning the franking privilege, and Mr Cushing, the Resolutions respecting the order of 18. January 1837. and Slavery in the District of Columbia, After presenting my Petitions, I offered a Resolution— [“]That the power of annexing the People of any independent foreign State to this Union is a power not delegated by the Constitution of the United States to their Congress, or to any department of their Government, but reserved to the People.” The Speaker refused to receive this motion or to allow it to be read; on the pretence that it was not in order— I appealed to the uniform practice of the House to receive with Petitions, Resolutions relating to the subject of them; but in vain. Cambreleng Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means, reported sundry Bills, among which one to appropriate 1600000 dollars for the suppression of Indian hostilities in Florida, and the Bill from the Senate to postpone the payment of the fourth instalment of the deposite with the States— He offered also a Resolution from the Committee, for the House to meet hereafter at 10. AM—which the House adopted, modifying the hour to 11— Arphaxed Loomis a New member from the State of New-York offered a Resolution of enquiry of the Secretary of the Treasury about the modes of keeping the public monies since the organization of the Government, and the losses sustained by the different modes, which after running the gauntlet of half a dozen amendments proposed and withdrawn was finally adopted. Gholson of Mississippi offered a Resolution instructing the Committee of Elections to report on
on the contested election of the members from Mississippi— Garland of Virginia presented his bill, containing the counter project for the sub-treasury system— It is to return in substance to the deposit State-Banks— Cambreleng called for the orders of the day— The House went in to Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, Haynes of Georgia in the Chair, and took up the Bill from the Senate—to postpone the payment of the fourth instalment of the deposit with the States— Cambreleng introduced the Bill, with a short Speech, and a statement of the denudated condition of the Treasury—a long debate arose in which Bell, Rhett, Thompson, John Sergeant, Hamer, Wise, and John Calhoun took part— Dawson of Georgia proposed as a substitute for the bill that the Secretary of the Treasury should suspend the payment of a portion of existing appropriations, sufficient to relieve the pressure upon the Treasury, without postponing the instalment— No question was taken and the House adjourned—about 1/2 past 3.— At the request of John Reed, I agreed to attend a meeting of the members of the Massachusetts delegation, in the Chamber of the Committee of Manufactures, at ten O’Clock to-morrow Morning—
19. III:30. Tuesday.

A Mrs Wade sent her son here to solicit alms, which I was unable to bestow— Meeting of the members of the Massachusetts delegation in the House; in the chamber of the Committee of Manufactures; then removed to that of the Committee of Foreign Affairs—present Adams, Borden, Briggs—Calhoun, Cushing, Fletcher, Grennell, Hastings, Lincoln, Phillips and Reed—absent only Parmenter.— There was much discussion about the Bill for postponing the payment of the fourth Deposit instalment. The hour elapsed, and we agreed to meet again at ten to-morrow.— The call for Petitions began at the Territory of Wisconsin— I presented a long memorial from Joseph Husband junr. of Baltimore, about currency, and banking and the like—referred at my motion to the Committee of Ways and Means— I presented also 39. petitions and remonstrances against the annexation of Texas; and asked leave to offer the Resolution which I had proposed yesterday denying the power of Congress to annex a foreign people to the Union—objection was made— I asked a suspension of the rules, and the yeas and nays upon the motion; both of which were denied— But after the call for Petitions was gone through, and that for Resolutions came up, I offered again the Resolution, which was received and at my own motion laid on the table— Other resolutions were offered— One by Martin of Alabama concerning the public Lands—one by Jenifer about tobacco—one by Patton; a Call upon the President for documents relating to the trial of Genl Scott and the command of Genl. Jesup.— One by Taliaferro, of Virginia—a call on the Secretary of the Treasury for a statement of imported bread-stuffs for the last ten years—and one by Wise, for the appointment by ballot of a Committee to investigate the Causes and conduct of the War in Florida— This last Resolution gave rise to a debate of more than an hour in which Cushing, and Glascock, and Duncan of Ohio, took leading parts, Cushing intending evidently to
to be placed on the Committee— Cambreleng finally called for the orders of the day: Bills from the Senate, to authorize the issuing of ten Millions of Treasury notes—to authorize a further postponement of payment upon duty bonds, and for adjusting the remaining claims upon the late deposit banks were twice read and referred to the Committee of Ways and means— Then the House went into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, Haynes in the chair.— Dawson withdrew, his proposed substitute for the deposit postponement Bill— Bell of Tennessee made a Speech of three hours against the Bill followed by Pickens— M’Kay and others— The Committee rose without coming to any Resolution, and the House adjourned about 4. O’Clock. Evening visit from Mr John Connell.
20. III:30. Wednesday.

Somewhat indisposed, and twice up in the Night— But at ten this morning we had the second meeting of the Massachusetts delegation, in the chamber of the Committee of foreign Affairs. We discussed for an hour the question upon this deposit postponement bill— Governor Lincoln as well as myself has a strong reluctance to vote against it, under an apprehension that there is no money in the Treasury to pay the instalment, and that it can be paid only by new taxation upon the People.— The other members of the delegation incline very strongly to vote against the Bill, especially in the form as it comes from the Senate— We came only to the conclusion to watch the progress of the Bill in the House; to vote for any amendment to it which may be proposed, reserving the final vote of yea or nay, as the bill may be made by amendment satisfactory or otherwise— H.R.U.S.— I presented 12 Petitions and remonstrances against the admission of Texas into the Union— Many others were presented by other members. Cambreleng from the Committee of Ways and Means reported the Bills from the Senate, authorizing the issuing of Treasury Notes, with two amendments; one a penal clause; the other an appropriation of half a Million—a bill for the postponement of the payment of duty bonds—and a Bill for the adjustment of the claims upon the late deposit banks, both without amendment.— All referred to the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union.— R. Biddle enquired of the Chairman of the Judiciary Committee F. Thomas, whether they intended to report a bankrupt Law; and whether it would be such as Mr Van Buren, when he was a member of the Senate of the United States thought unconstitutional— Thomas said he could not give a satisfactory answer. That the Committee had had two Meetings—the second called by a member when he was absent; and at which nothing had been decided—but that he would give a further answer to-morrow— Wise’s Resolution for a Committee to investigate the Causes and conduct of the Florida War was discussed, till Cambreleng called for the orders of the day— Holsey of Georgia made a tomahawk and scalping knife speech— Cushing had objected to the appointment of the Committee by ballot— Wise in reply insisted upon it, and referring to his investigating Committee of last Winter declared that not one line of the report of the majority of that Committee was
was written by any member of the Committee— That it was written by a Scavenger—An Anti-masonic editor brought from Boston, by Dutee J. Pearce and made the Clerk of the Committee.— Pearce he said was not now in the house, and ought not to be in the Country. Wise’s speech was bitter as wormwood. Cambreleng called for the orders of the day.— The deposit postponement bill was taken up— Cambreleng replied feebly to Bell’s attack upon the bill yesterday. Underwood of Kentucky followed— Pickens of South-Carolina offered an amendment, totally changing the character of the Bill— The Bill postpones the payment of the fourth instalment; till further provided for by Congress— It purports to be postponement. It is really a repeal of the Law requiring the payment.— Pickens proposes to strike out the words, till further provided for by Congress, and to insert, till the first of January 1839. Duncan of Ohio supported the Bill— Garland of Virginia, promised to vote for it; and Biddle opposed it— Loomis of Ohio moved that the Committee should rise which was carried and the House adjourned, about 4 O’Clock— Mrs W. S. Smith—Robert Buchanan and Mr Frye, were here separately after dinner— Mr Frye was complaining of a Bill concerning the District Banks; but was called away, by a cry of fire; which proved a false alarm— My indisposition continues; and affects my voice— John Wilson was here this morning.— He is about to leave the service of the French Minister, and proposes to set up a Hack.
21. III:30. Thursday

I was again twice up in the Night, and have also lost my voice— H.R.U.S. I presented the petition of John Gardiner, praying compensation for the invention of a Life-preserver, to save persons in cases of shipwreck from drowning— I believe it is the old Cork jacket— Laid on the table as were 12 petitions against the annexation of Texas to the Union which I also presented. Ewing presented a petition for a National Bank; and asked leave to offer with it a few remarks, but was refused.— Howard of Maryland presented a petition from claimants of indemnity for French spoliations before the year 1800. and was allowed to offer with it a few remarks. Thomas, Chairman of the judiciary Committee, announced to the House that the Committee had this morning adopted a Resolution that it is inexpedient to report a Bankrupt Law, at the present Session of the Congress.— Wise’s Resolution for an investigation of the Florida War was taken up— Cushing withdrew his objection to the appointment of the Committee by ballot. Glascock moved an amendment for the appointment of a Committee, with authority to send for persons and papers— Howard of Maryland moved by way of amendment to Glascock’s amendment, that the reference should be to the Military Committee— Muhlenberg reproached Wise, for his attacks yesterday upon D. J. Pearce, and Hallett; and said he presumed Pearce had written the Report of the Majority.— Wise replied—respectfully to Muhlenberg— Severely, upon the Military Committee.— Wise called upon Governor Lincoln to prove that Pearce, had acknowledged to him that the report of the majority was written by Hallett, and Lincoln did confirm the assertion. The House passed to the orders of the day and went into Committee of the whole on the Union, and took up the bill to postpone the payment of the fourth instalment of the deposit with the States— The amendment proposed
proposed by Pickens was under consideration, but the Speakers ranged through the whole system of policy of the administration; Loomis of Ohio made an elaborate assault upon the Bill— John W. Jones of Virginia followed in support of the Bill in an elaborate and well delivered speech; I believe the first he has made in three Sessions of Congress— Atherton of New Hampshire came next in a very feeble speech sustaining the bill— Foster favoured Pickens’s amendment, and Briggs opposed the Bill— At Mercer’s Motion the Committee rose and the House adjourned— Howard of Maryland came to my Seat, and told me that the Painters employed to fill up the pannels yet failing in the Rotunda had chosen their Subjects— One the landing of Columbus— One John Smith of Virginia— The third subject he did not recollect; but the fourth was the departure of the Massachusetts Colony from England— He also told me that the Mexican and Texian correspondence called for by my Resolutions, would be sent to the House in two or three days— And that a proposition to Mexico to cede Texas to the United States, was in the instructions to Poinsett under my administration.— I invited Mr John Sergeant to go home and dine with me, which he did— Robert C. Buchanan was here in the Evening.
22. III:15. Friday

Still much indisposed. Morning visit from Mr Briggs, and Mr Theodore Sedgwick of Stockbridge, Massachusetts. H.R.US.
