I presented 13 petitions and remonstrances against the annexation of Texas to the Union; among which two from the City of New-York, one of 581 men, and one of 4793 women— Some others were presented by other members.— The Speaker presented the thanks of a numerous Temperance meeting at Philadelphia, to Congress for the recent joint order of the two houses prohibiting the sale of spirituous liquors within and around the Capitol— Wise’s Resolution for investigation of the Florida War was taken up.— He noticed an inaccuracy of a report in both papers of a passage in his yesterday’s Speech— Gholson of Mississippi, a member of the Military Committee, with his own election contested, and unquestionably null and void, made a Speech in favour of the reference to the Military Committee, and bitter and insulting to Wise— Campbell of South-Carolina, made some remarks upon Wise’s statement respecting the members brother Coll. Campbell’s conduct in the investigating Committee of last Winter— Wise rose to reply to Gholson; but Cambreleng called for the orders of the day.— The Committee of the whole on the State of the Union, Haynes in the Chair, and the Deposit postponement Bill— Speeches against it were made by C. Shepard of North-Carolina and Sibley of New-York—and by Cushman, Holsey, Fairfield, and Parker in its favour.— It was about 4. O’Clock when Smith of Maine took the floor and moved that the Committee should rise, which Cambreleng totis viribus opposed, and said that if the bill should not be passed within one week the Treasury
Treasury must stop.— The Committee nevertheless rose— Patton moved the House to adjourn— Cambreleng called for the yeas and nays, and the adjournment was carried 96. to 85— I came home about 5 O’Clock quite unwell— Mrs. W. S. Smith, and Mr Frye, were separately here after dinner— I walked part of the way home with a member whom I did not know; but found it was Arphaxed Loomis, the successor of Abijah Mann jr. of New-York.
23. III:30. Saturday.

In the House of Representatives, without the bar, I saw Mr. Edwards, heretofore a member of the House from North Carolina, and W. S. Archer, many years a member of the House from Virginia— He lost his election to the last Congress, by opposing Jackson’s administration in the controversy with France, and is exceedingly sore under his disappointment— He says the Country has been six years under the most contemptible despotism that ever disgraced a Nation— On motion of Mr Haynes of Georgia, it was ordered that the hour of meeting for the House after next Monday, for the remainder of the Session should be ten O’Clock— I presentedPetitions for the abolition of Slavery &c in the District of Columbia— Upon Wise’s Resolution for an investigation of the causes and conduct of the War in Florida being called he made a tart speech, answered by squirts of wormwood from Gholson of Mississippi— Arphaxed Loomis took up the cudgel in behalf of his predecessor Abijah Mann junr. whom Wise had roughly handled; but Loomis made not much of his case— He is as sly and trickish as Mann; but more timid, and of oracular gravity— Cambreleng called for the orders of the day— Cushing asked Cambreleng if he intended to close the discussion in the Committee of the whole, on the deposit postponement bill, this day. Cambreleng said he did.— Cushing asked if the discussion was to be choked off; and was called to order.— Cambreleng had said in Committee of the whole, that circumstances had occurred since the passage of this Bill, and of the Bill for adjusting the balances due from the deposit banks in the Senate which rendered the passage of the postponement bill, indispensable; or within a week the Treasury would be dry— Rice Garland—now enquired what those circumstances were— The Speaker said it was not in order to refer in the House to any thing that had been said in Committee of the whole—but afterwards Cambreleng answered Garland’s question— He said that since the passage in the Senate of those two bills; the merchants did not want Treasury drafts to pay their bonds, and the banks saw they would not be compelled to pay their balances— The bonds and balances had therefore both become unavailable funds, and the Treasury was ashore. Fairfield and Smith of Maine, Waddy Thompson and Halstead of New-Jersey discussed the postponement bill till near 5 O’Clock, when at the motion of Christopher H. Williams a new Member from Tennessee the Committee rose. Garland of Virginia, said he should be obliged to go home, upon family concerns next Wednesday, and would therefore on Monday submit to the House his counterproject to the Sub-treasuries. Adjourned at 5— Robert. C Buchanan was here in the Evening; and asked me to write some verses, for a young Lady of his acquaintance Miss Caroline Goldsborough.
24. V. Sunday.

Heard at the Presbyterian Church, a Scotchman named Blood, from John 3.16: “For God so loved the world, that he gave his only begotten Son, that whosoever believeth in him should not perish, but have everlasting life.”— The text is familiar to the Calvinistic doctrines— The preacher was more eloquent in purpose than in execution— Very earnest and very feeble. Old Mr Joseph Nourse, and his wife were in the pew— Mr Phillips and Robert C. Buchanan dined with me. Mr Phillips went with me after dinner to St. John’s Church; Mr Hawley read the Service for the 18th. Sunday after Trinity, and preached from Psalm 68:18. [“]Thou hast ascended on high; thou hast led captivity captive: thou hast received gifts for man; yea for the rebellious also, that the Lord God might dwell among them.” It is not always easy to perceive in Mr Hawley’s Sermon, what prompted him to the selection of his text.— Robert C Buchanan was here again, with his half-brother Thomas J. Frye, in the Evening—and afterwards Hiram Powars the Sculptor, who is to sail from New-York for Italy on the first of next Month, and who asked me for a Letter of introduction— I promised him one to Richard H. Wilde— I revised also a Sonnet, addressed to Miss Caroline Goldsborough. I received this morning a Letter from David Strang, a native of Scotland, settled at Covington, Genesee County, New-York— He says he has been five years in this Country, and intends to remain here; but does not say whether he has been naturalized or not— With the Letter, is a petition or Memorial to Congress on the subject of banks, banking and currency.
25. III:30 Monday.

John Adlington, a man upwards of 80 years of age, a Yankee from the crown of his head to the soles of his feet, came from Plymouth here, all the way, for an increase of pension from 8 dollars a Month, as for a common Seaman, to 16 dollars a Month as a Midshipman in 1775, before the Declaration of Independence— He came also to claim arrears of pay (which he said he had never received for subsequent services in the same War[)]. I took his papers to the pension Office, and left them together—with others which I had received in a Letter from Mr Jacob H Loud of Plymouth, with Mr Edwards the Commissioner— I then went to the Office of the Secretary of the Navy, and left with him a Letter from my nephew and namesake Midshipman, asking for orders—and I made application for Thomas Spooner now a private in the Marine Corps; soliciting an appointment of Lieutenant in the Corps, which Mr Dickerson told me could not be granted. H.R.U.S. Cambreleng from the Committee of Ways and Means reported a Resolution that it is inexpedient to charter a National Bank— The object of this is to supersede the discussion of Wise’s Resolution for an investigation of the Causes and conduct of the Florida War.— I had presented the memorial of David Strang, and had it referred to the Committee of Ways and Means; and I had also presentedPetitions against the annexation
annexation of Texas to the Union; and a budget of those of the last Session for the abolition of Slavery in the District of Columbia— Chambers of Kentucky offered a Petition for a National Bank, and said he had several others which he should in due time move to have referred to the Committee of the whole on the Union; but he moved that this one should lie on the table—which was done— Ewing asked leave to offer a Resolution calling on the Secretary of the Treasury for returns of the specie and paper received in payment for public Lands—but the leave, and the suspension of the rules which he moved, were both refused— Buchanan Chairman of the Committee of Elections made a report on the Mississippi Election, concluding with a Resolution that Gholson and Claiborne, have been duly elected members of the 25th. Congress— Maury, a member of the Committee said the minority would not present a counter-report; but would exhibit their views in the form of a proposed amendment to the Resolution.— There was a discussion whether the subject should be debated in the morning hour, or referred to the Committee of the whole on the Union; and the morning hour prevailed— Postponed till Wednesday.— Everett moved that the Resolution of the inexpediency of a National Bank, should be laid on the table— Lost, by yeas and nays 89 to 122. In Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, the deposit postponement Bill was debated, Haynes in the Chair till one O’Clock in the Morning— Martin of Alabama moved an amendment to the Bill, which the Chairman received, while Pickens’s amendment was yet undecided— The whole day was consumed in debating neither of the amendments, but the Bill and the whole financeering system of the administration—at dusk of evening an attempt was made to adjourn which failed; a second and third motion for the Committee to rise were alike unsuccessful, the third vote by tellers being 84 and 84. lost by the casting vote of the chairman— Shortly before midnight I enquired if Martin’s amendment was in order—the Chairman said, not strictly, but he had entertained it for reasons which he was about to assign, when Martin withdrew it— I then moved an amendment to Pickens’s amendment—appropriating the balances due from all the late deposit Banks to the payment of the 4th. deposit on the 1st. of January 1839. declaring that they shall be applied to no other purpose whatever—providing that if the balances recoverable from the banks should not prove sufficient for the payment in 1839. the instalment due from the Bank of the United States in October 1838. for Stock should be applied to the same purpose—and in failure of that, pledging the faith of the United States that provision shall be made by Congress for the payment— I made a very few observations in offering the amendment, being so hoarse that I could speak only with extreme difficulty, and so as scarcely to reach the Chairman’s ear— W. Cost Johnson, Chambers and Underwood of Kentucky—and Mr Pope, afterwards addressed the Chair, till after one O’Clock the motion for the Committee to rise was renewed by C. F. Mercer— The tellers reported 90 for and 89. against rising—the Committee rose and the House adjourned— It was 2. A.M when I reached home.
26. V:30. Tuesday.

I came home this morning with a heavy head-ache and otherwise unwell— I had no sleep, and rose after the dawn, but before the Sun; relieved from my head ache; but with spirits dissipated making it impossible for me to write— John Adlington was here again with his hearing interpreter; for he is deaf— I had not received the report from the Commissioner of Pensions upon his papers; but he said his cash was short, and he must make the best of his way home; and wait for me to send his answer from the Pension Office and his papers to Mr Jacob H. Loud of Plymouth.— H.R.U.S. at 10. O’Clock A.M. I presentedPetitions and Memorials for the abolition of Slavery; and multitudes were presented by other members— Dunn and Ewing of Indiana offered Resolutions of Call upon the Secretary of the Treasury— That of Dunn was received and adopted— That of Ewing was not ever received.— Ewing renewed his motion, and Williams of North-Carolina called for the yeas and nays— They were 97 to 76. not two thirds—and thus the rule formed for the protection of the minority, was abused to their oppression. Johnson of Louisiana offered a Resolution, requiring of the Secretary of War, to prepare for the first week of the Winter Session, a plan for the protection of the Western frontier against Indian Aggressions; which has over a day.— The Resolution from the Committee of Ways and Means that it is inexpedient to Charter a National Bank was opposed by Read and Sergeant, and amendments were offered by Wise, Bell, and Pope.— The Speaker laid before the House, an answer from the Secretary of the Treasury to Call for correspondence and statements relating to the deposit Banks A Resolution from the Senate for closing the Session on the 9th. of next Month was taken up, and passionately opposed by Bell, who said it was an insult to the House— Cambreleng moved the previous question, but could not carry it— He then moved to postpone the consideration of the Resolution till next Monday at 11. O’Clock, and make it the special order for that time— I asked leave to move an amendment to strike out the 9th. of October, and insert the first Monday in April next—but the Speaker refused to receive my motion. Mercer had moved a call for a statement from the Clerk of the House shewing the cost of this extra session; but his motion was rejected— He asked that it might be laid on the table and printed, and called for the yeas and nays on this motion but all was refused— Robertson laid on the table an amendment which he gave notice that he should propose when in order, to the deposit postponement bill— The House then went into Committee of the whole, Haynes in the Chair on that bill— Mercer made a Speech of nearly two hours, generally against the Bill.— He was followed by Rencher, Taylor of New-York and Bond of Ohio.— Wise, Ewing and Jenifer expressed the wish to speak; and upon a promise to Jenifer by Cambreleng that the previous question should not be sprung upon him in the house—the question was taken by tellers on my amendment to that of Pickens which was lost 89 to 104—on that of Pickens which was lost 84 to 110, and on other amendments proposed by Underwood and others; all of which were rejected— The Committee then rose and reported the Bill without Amendment— A Message was received from the President, with the Brazilian correspondence of William Tudor’s Negotiations—and the answer to my
to my call for the correspondence relating to the North-eastern boundary but neither the Mexican, Nor the Texan correspondence was sent. W. S. Archer told me the other day that a great majority of the People of Texas were not desirous of annexation to this Union, but averse to it— That is a cunning way of stimulating us to desire it. The House adjourned at half-past six; and I came exhausted home.
27. IV. Wednesday.

Wilson was here this morning, and enquired if I could conveniently pay my note to him— He has purchased a Hack and a pair of horses for which he wants the money to pay— I gave him a check for 200 dollars, which he said was all he wanted now, and I promised to pay him the remainder immediately after the close of the Session— H.R.U.S. Joseph L. Williams, a new member from Tennessee took his Seat. I presentedPetitions—chiefly for the abolition of Slavery in the District of Columbia— I presented particularly—Several Resolutions were offered, among which one by R. Biddle, to refer the Report of the Secretary of the Treasury concerning his discriminitive specie payments to the Committee of Ways and Means for enquiry into the expediency of legislative regulation. But the yeas and nays on the motion to suspend the rules were 85 to 102. Thomas Chairman of the Committee on the judiciary offered a Resolution instructing the Committee to enquire what Laws would expire at the close of the present Session of Congress, and to report a Bill to continue in force such of them as ought to be continued, which was adopted— Cost Johnson of Maryland, Mallory of Virginia, Williams of North-Carolina and Stanley successively offered Resolutions, and Ewing at last succeeded in getting his received, but not considered— It lies over, a day—that is to the end of the Session— The Resolution from the Committee of Ways and Means that it is inexpedient to establish a National Bank was postponed till next Saturday J. Sergeant, who had yesterday commenced a Speech against it being indisposed and unable to proceed in it to day— Smith of Maine, moved the printing of 5000 copies of the correspondence relating to the North-eastern boundary, for which I had called— Sawyer of North-Carolina objected, but withdrew the objection at my request.— I asked Smith to include the Brazilian correspondence in his motion, but he declined— His motion was agreed to. I then asked leave to move for the printing of an equal number of the Brazilian Correspondence, but objection was made, and I desisted— Patton from the Library Committee offered a Resolution respecting the purchase and publication of the Papers of the late James Madison, which was adopted— Maury of Tennessee; offered an amendment to the Report of the Committee of Elections, declaring Gholson and Claiborne duly elected members of the 25th. Congress— The amendment declares them not duly elected. Pennybacker of Virginia, another member of the Committee replied to Maury; till the orders of the day were called, and the deposit postponement Bill, was taken up in Committee of the whole— Jenifer of Maryland, opposed the Bill in a speech which I did not hear, and which was not worth hearing. He was followed byMenefee, a new and young member from Kentucky of great talent and promise— He is said to be called in Kentucky the young Henry Clay; and his Speech proved him worthy of the appellation— It was powerful and eloquent— Fry of Pennsylvania made a short and shallow
shallow Speech in favour of the Bill, and was succeeded by Potter, also of Pennsylvania, who canted like a methodist Preacher.— He read from a newspaper a part of my Letter to William Foster, and censured it— A highly spirited debate then followed—by Wise, in one of his best and most pungent speeches, in which he alluded to Cambreleng’s Letter to Flagg— Cambreleng denied that he had used the expression in that Letter “we have got the banks upon the hip.” said that he had no ill will to the Banks; but that Wise should have assailed me, who had compared the Presidents and Directors of all the Banks in the Union to counterfeitors. He promised Wise to send him to-morrow morning a copy of his Letter to Flagg, if he would make it a part of his Speech—which Wise promised to do. Cambreleng said his letter was not against the Banks, but censured the Legislatures for legalizing the violation by the Banks of their engagements— Hamer of Ohio answered Wise, with all his power which is not small— Dawson of Georgia, began by enquiring of Cambreleng whether the Bill for the relief of the deposit Banks was to pass the House? Cambreleng said he could not answer for others— He expected it would— Dawson then asked him whether the deposit Banks of New-York were solvent or insolvent— Cambreleng answered with hesitation that some were solvent—others not—one at least he believed was not Dawson put the same question to Duncan, concerning the Banks of Ohio— Duncan answered that he believed the Banks were good; but their paper was depretiated from 10 to 14. per cent. Johnson of Louisiana and Martin of Alabama, answered for the banks of their respective States— Dawson said he would not put the same question respecting the Bank of Missouri, lest it should give offence—but he would receive with pleasure any information from the members from that State which they might be disposed to give—none was given.— Whittlesey took up the cause of the Banks of Ohio, insisting that they were all, save one, as sound and solvent as any others in the Union— There was some discussion upon this between Whittlesey, Bond, Hamer and Duncan— Dawson commenced a Speech against the Bill—but nearly at 8 O’Clock yielded to a motion to adjourn, which was carried— Bouldin said to me that his great objection to the National Bank was because it was against the interests of the South— That if they would locate a Bank at Charleston or New-Orleans, he would either vote for it; or go home and send here a man who would— Mr Gales gave me Stansberry’s report of my very few remarks made on presenting my amendment last Evening.— Near 9 when I got home—
28. III:15. Thursday

H.R.U.S.— I presentedPetitions for the abolition of Slavery in the Territoriesfor refusing the admission of any new Slaveholding State into the Union—andfor the prohibition of the interstate Slave trade— With the last I asked leave to offer a Resolution, calling upon the Secretary of the Treasury, to report at the next Session of Congress the numbers of Slaves exported from, and imported into the several Ports of the United States, by the Coasting trade— There was what Napoleon would have called a superb no! returned to my request, from the servile side of the House— Sherrod Williams asked for the printing of 3 Resolutions which he intends to offer for the establishment of a national Bank; and it was ordered— Stanley and Toland, failed to obtain the consideration of Resolutions, which they wished to offer. Snyder of Illinois offered a Resolution of enquiry of the Secretary of the Treasury what amount of Specie was in the Bank of Missouri on
on the 5th. of July and on the 16th. of August 1837.— Harlan of Kentucky, and Bronson of New-York, discussed during the remnant of the morning hour the Mississippi Section— Then the orders of the day and the deposit postponement Bill came up, introduced by Mr Cambreleng who made a recanting and disclaiming apology for his discrediting remarks of yesterday upon the New-York banks— He now pronounced them all solvent, with indulgence of time; and said he had no hostile feelings towards gentlemen concerned in those institutions; but what he had censured and resisted was improper and intrusive legislation, upon the subject.— Dawson and Townes of Georgia addressed the house in long speeches, one against the other for the deposit postponement Bill. Graves of Kentucky, followed against it— In the midst of his Speech, Mercer moved a recess of an hour for the members to dine— A half an hour’s debate ensued which ended in a resolution to take the recess of an hour this day, and from half past 2 till 4. O’Clock every day hereafter till the end of the Session— An hour and a half is precisely the time that it takes me to walk home from the Capitol, and back again. So I cannot go home to dine— I repaired to the Chamber of the Committee of Manufactures, but the door was locked, and the key not to be found— I wrote during the recess a Letter to my wife— When the Speaker resumed the chair, Graves concluded his Speech which was in his manner—animated, and with very rapid elocution—but diffuse and full of repetitions ad nauseam— Cushman of New Hampshire then moved the Previous Question, and Haynes of Georgia moved a Call of the House— The previous Question, which cut off my amendment and that of Pickens was carried by yeas and nays. 123 to 102— The passage of the Bill to a third reading by 119 to 117. Immediately after the vote was declared, Pickens moved a reconsideration of it, and said he had voted in the affirmative for that express purpose— The real vote then was a tie 118 and 118. and the largest vote ever given in the House of Representatives of the United States 237. members including the Speaker, present and voting out of 242— The House adjourned at 8. O’Clock. I walked part of the way home with Cambreleng, and noticed the closeness of his vote— He said the House would probably reconsider, and adopt Pickens’s amendment— In the National Intelligencer of this day, the very few remarks with which I introduced the amendment in Committee of the whole on the Union—well reported by Stansbury—
29. III:30. Friday

H.R.U.S— I reached the House, at the instant of time to present 51 petitions and remonstrances against the order of the House of Representatives of the 18th. of January 1837—which was to lay on the table without printing or further action of the House upon them all Petitions, Resolutions and Papers in any manner relating to Slavery— Most of these were received by me during the last Session, but the majority of the House by evading after the 6th. of February the reception of all Petitions, excluded the reception of these, and of 150 others, all of which I have now presented and they have all been received and laid on the table.— Toland of Pennsylvania offered a Resolution of Call upon the Secretary of the Treasury for copies of all correspondence and Documents of the Department with individuals Banks and Corporations, relating to the Bill for issuing Treasury notes, which lies over one day— Stanley resolution of enquiry, concerning the number and cost of
of the proposed sub-treasuries, was adopted—but Ewing solicited in vain the consideration of the Resolution, which he has several days pressed upon the courtesy of the House— Cambreleng from the Committee of Ways and Means, reported a Bill of additional appropriations for the year 1837.— Read twice and referred to the Committee of the whole House on the state of the Union— As was a Bill reported by Thomas, Chairman of the Judiciary Committee, to continue till the end of the next Session of Congress all laws which would expire with the present Session— The Mississippi election was next debated— Turney of Tennessee supported the report of the majority of the Committee, and Towns of Georgia, opposed it— Towns was a member of the Committee, and although devoted to the administration, dissented from the report of the majority, in favour of the sitting Mississippi Members— Robertson of Virginia, spoke also against the report of the Committee until the orders of the day were called, when at the instance of Gholson and Claiborne, the subject was postponed till next Monday, and made the special order for that day.— The Speaker laid before the House, an answer from the Secretary of the Treasury to a call respecting the suspension of payments on the Merchants bonds— The deposit postponement bill coming up, the first question to be decided was the motion of Mr Pickens for reconsideration of the vote passing the bill to a third reading.— Pickens urged his own amendment as an argument for reconsideration, and I urged my amendment to his amendment, to the same point. I noticed particularly an assertion of Waddy Thompson in a speech the other day, that the natural tendency of this Government was that all the money of the Nation, flowed to the North— I treated the whole subject with pleasantry, much to the amusement of the house, and with some impression— Sergeant said to me, as we were going out of the house, at the recess, that every word I had spoken, drew blood— Waddy Thompson admitted that he had said all the money of the Nation flowed to the North— Lyon of Alabama, and Gholson of Mississippi, made some remarks on my allusions to the enormous deposits of public monies in the banks of their respective States, to which I replied— Gray of New-York and Everett of Vermont spoke in favour of the reconsideration— Arphaxed Loomis, successor of Abijah Mann junr. moved the previous question, but withdrew it, at the request of Toucey of Connecticut who began a speech which was interrupted by the recess— I passed it in the chamber of the Committee of Manufactures, writing a Letter to my wife— When the Speaker resumed the Chair Toucey finished his Speech, weak as water, for the bill, as a repeal, of the fourth instalment— Cambreleng moved the previous question and a call of the House— 215 members answered to their names— The previous question was carried, and the vote for reconsideration 149 to 81. Cambreleng voted against it, but allowing it to be carried by his rank and file— Pickens then moved his amendment limiting the payment of the fourth instalment to the 1st. of January 1839— Haynes moved an amendment to it a proviso, that there should be a sufficient surplus in the Treasury: which Pickens said he himself would cheerfully have accepted, but to which his friends would not assent.— Haynes withdrew his amendment and I offered mine: appropriating the balances in the deposit banks; the instalment of the debt to be due in October 1838 from the bank of the United States, and pledging the Faith of the United States, to the payment on the 1st. of January 1839. the last clause of which however I consented to withdraw— Phillips made a
a very singular Speech; ostensibly in support of my amendment; but in reality against the postponement of the instalment, and an argument for making the payment at once by an issue of Treasury Notes— Patton by an obliquity of the rational faculty not less remarkable without objecting to Pickens’s amendment, flatly rejected mine, and said if it should be adopted he would vote against the Bill— His motive was the dastardly fear of reproach from his constituents for supporting any motion offered by me— There are at least 95 representatives of Slaves in the House, under the same servile fear.— Arphaxed Loomis, advised me to change the word pay, in my amendment for the word deposit— I said it was a mere mutation of words and not of thought; but that to accomodate him I would accept his modification, if he would then vote for my amendment; but he declined— My amendment was lost by a vote of 94 to 135.— Williams of North-Carolina moved to lay the bill and amendments on the table—lost 101. to 132— Bell moved to refer the bill and amendments back to the Committee of the whole on the Union with Instructions to report another Bill nearly the same with my amendment—rejected without counting— Phillips then moved a recommit with instructions to report a Bill for paying the deposit, and issuing Treasury notes payable in a year with interest—rejected without count, and with refusal of the yeas and nays— Mason of Virginia, moved to substitute a Bill to repeal the 4th. instalment—lost—so were sundry other proposed amendments, and at last the previous question was carried, and the bill passed to a third reading—by a vote of 118 to 105— The third reading was called for immediately. Garland of Louisiana, wished it postponed until the Bill for settling accounts with the late deposit Banks shall have been taken up and amended— The balances due from the Banks of Alabama, Louisiana, Mississippi and Michigan are so heavy that they cannot pay them within the term of nine months proposed in the settlement Bill— Garland was afraid, if this postponement Bill should pass before a longer term than nine months should be secured to the Louisiana Banks than the Settlement bill proposes, those Banks will be at the mercy of the Secretary of the Treasury.— Gholson of Mississippi pleaded also very hard for the postponement. Cambreleng to whom the votes of the members from those States were indispensable, promised that if they would vote for this bill, their banks should be treated with indulgence— Dawson of Georgia, and Sampson Mason of Ohio indignantly pointed out to the House this shameless bargain—thus struck in the face of the House.— But after some discussion, M’Kim moved the previous question which was carried, and the Bill without taking the yeas and nays was read the third time and passed— The Speaker laid before the House two Executive reports, and the House at 11 O’Clock at Night adjourned— On Pickens’s amendment, and on the passage of the Bill to the third reading Patton bolted—he left the house and did not vote at all— He had not said a word against Pickens’s amendment nor against the Bill; but he had made a Speech against my amendment and said if it should be adopted he would vote against the Bill— It were a curious enquiry to trace the small motives which turn the balance of deliberation upon great National concerns— It was near Midnight when I got home— It had been raining all day— Walk with M’Kennan—
30. V:30. Saturday

My occupations break down all succession of Time. When I reached the Capitol this morning, I found the House in Session. The Speaker was calling for Petitions from the Pennsylvania members, having begun with the Territory of Wisconsin.— After disburthening myself of all the Petitions which had been left upon my hands at the close of the last Session of Congress, I had none this morning to present. Other members presented petitions, for the abolition of Slavery, and against the annexation of Texas— Toland’s Resolution offered yesterday, calling upon the Secretary of the Treasury for correspondence relating to the Treasury Note Bill now before the House, after some discussion was adopted— Cambreleng from the Committee of Ways and Means reported without amendment a Bill from the Senate a Bill to remit the duties on goods destroyed by fire in the City of New-York; and with an amendment, a Bill for extending the time for the payment of duties on merchants’ Bonds. Dunn of Indiana, moved a reference to the Committee on the Judiciary, of a report from the Secretary of the Treasury, and an opinion of the Attorney General concerning duty bonds. Sergeant continued, without concluding his Speech on the Resolution that it is inexpedient to establish a National Bank; and Robertson of Virginia moved as an amendment, that no such institution ought ever to be chartered without a previous amendment of the Constitution expressly delegating the power to Congress.— Orders of the day. Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, Connor in the Chair— Cambreleng calls for the Bill for issuing ten Millions of Treasury Notes— The Clerk takes up the House Bill, and reads to the words “without interest,” when Cambreleng stops him and tells him he must take up the Senate’s Bill, which he does and reads it through— Bell then objects that it is a Bill to raise revenue, and appeals to me.— I had started the objection in my speech of yesterday, without making any apparent impression upon the house— I now said that if ever there was a Bill to raise revenue this was that Bill— I would offer no motion, for I knew that if I did it would immediately be voted down; but if he would open the discussion, he should have my cordial support— Haynes interrupted me by a Question of order and said it was too late to raise the objection— Wise said it could never be too late for a Constitutional objection, and moved that the Committee should rise; that the Bill might be sent back to the Senate— I enquired of the Chairman whether Wise’s motion superseded Haynes’s question of order— Connor answered, in the opinion of the Chairman it does.— Cambreleng sputtered about the necessities of the Treasury— Said this was not a Bill to raise revenue—that the compromise Bill of 1833 originated in the Senate, and complained of the desire of the opposition to trammel the necessary operations of the Government— Mercer replied—and denied that the compromise bill had originated in the Senate— Robertson said that this was the most flagrant breach of the privileges of the House that ever was perpetrated— The House was kindling into a flame, upon a spark that I had dropped yesterday; when Cambreleng gave way, and moved to take up the House’s Bill; which after some opposition was done, and then he moved the Bill from the Senate, as an amendment to that of the House— Robert Barnwall Rhett (Smith heretofore) moved a long amendment, and literally howled, a nullification Speech— I say howled for his enunciation was so rapid
rapid, inarticulate, and vociferous, that his head hung back, as he spoke with his face upward, like that of a howling dog. A skirmishing debate followed, and at 1/2 past 2 the House adjourned over to Monday— I offered a Resolution of Call upon the Secretary of the Treasury for returns of the amount of gold and silver received by the Receivers of Public monies and deposit Banks under the specie circular. Haynes objected to this Call; but upon a hint from Cambreleng withdrew his objection, and the Resolution was adopted— As I was coming down the steps of the Capitol, a man by the name of Towle stopped me and inquired if I would sit to Mrs Towle for my Portrait— I stopped with him at his house; which is the same, where Powars had his moulding room— I saw Mrs Towle, and her collection of Portraits, consisting of Van Buren, R. M. Johnson—Polk the Speaker, T. H. Benton, Amos Kendall, and H. A. Wise, unfinished— I was not over-ambitious to appear in such company, meme en peinture, as old Count Löwenhielm said he would not like to reside at Delft— Nor was I much charmed with the execution of Mrs Towle’s Portraits— Yet as an act of courtesy, I promised to sit; if during the Winter Session I should have leisure— Evening at home— Robert C Buchanan was here.— His furlough expires next Wednesday, and he goes for Baton rouge— He renewed a request that I would send him any documents relating to the army. [symbols]

Day. I rise between 3 and 5 every morning— Write in this Diary till 8. Yet find it impossible to keep pace with the current of Time— Breakfast— Receive Letters and News papers— Walk to the Capitol to be there precisely at 10. when the Chaplain makes a prayer of two minutes, and the Speaker takes the Chair— In the House till the recess from 1/2 past 2 till 4. P. M—pass that time in the Cock-loft of the Committee of Manufactures with 5 or 6. small crackers and a glass of water— Write a Letter—return to the House— Sit till the adjournment 8. 9. 10. or later— Walk home— Take a cup of Cocoa— With or without a cold steak or chop—and to bed— My health on the whole good.
